messages.content:
how can we update this activity to make it also about resource savings and [[[1 hour: Activity (you can find an alternate online activity on the drive)
5 Minutes: Explanation
Entrepreneurs will work in groups to go through a rapid product development process.
Tell everyone they are a business developing a new product that will be sold to the training team: a paper airplane. The plane has to fly and look good. The price will reflect its design, functionality, and how efficiently it is produced. Based on the trainers' thoughts on your plane, they will give your plane a selling price.
Break the group into small teams (about 3 people per team).
The trainer should have prototyping materials ready, including paper, markers, stickers, etc. These items are available to the entrepreneurs to continue using as they want throughout the entire game. They can use whatever they want.
Entrepreneurs are free to continue asking the trainers (the people buying the planes) questions about the activity/type of plane to design (they can do user research to find out more about how to design their plane based on customers' needs/wants).
Entrepreneurs should feel free to work with their groups wherever they are comfortable.
55 Minutes: Activity
10 minutes: The team will have 10 minutes to design a new product (paper airplane). Encourage them to consider how to make an effective design while using materials efficiently.
10 minutes: Each group will pitch their plane to the trainer.
The trainer will evaluate functionality, design, and the overall pitch to determine a price for each plane.
The trainer can also consider the amount of work that went into the plane design. Did the team create a design that maximized performance while minimizing wasted materials?
The trainer should set prices like $2, $5, $10, $15, $20 depending on detail and flying capabilities. Try to have a variety of prices.
Tell them that each plane costs $5 to make (make it all the same to keep it simple). When we price the plane, some people will get better margins or worse margins.
And some people would be able to produce a lot or a little, causing different levels of profitability. Some designs might be more efficient, allowing for faster production or lower costs. It depends on how the game goes, but interesting conversations come up.
15 Minutes: Scaling Up the Production
Announce to the groups that you like all of the planes they pitched and you would like to purchase them for your store.
They will have 10 minutes to produce 15 of the planes they pitched.
Halfway through this time (after about 7 minutes), announce a change in demand:
You are expecting high demand for these planes after a focus group, and you would like to order 25 planes instead.
Announce that you will extend the delivery time by 5 additional minutes (13 minutes left for production).
15 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion
Bring everyone back and tell people production has stoppedâ€”they must now deliver their products.
The trainer will now pay each group for their product.
Count each plane that matches the one they pitched. Reject planes that do not work or do not match what they pitched to you.
Multiply the number of accepted planes by the price that was set before mass production.
Subtract $5 for each plane they made (even if the plane was rejected because they produced it).
Calculate who made the most money!
Trainer Tip: Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each $ of profit they made. (Some teams might realize that a more efficient process leads to higher profits!) Some people might owe you candy at the end if they werenâ€™t profitableâ€¦. But donâ€™t actually make them give you candy.

[[Original Version]]
5 minutes: Explanation
Entrepreneurs will work in groups to go through a rapid product development process.
Tell everyone they are a business developing a new product that will be sold to the training team: a paper airplane. The plane has to fly and look good. Based on the trainers thoughts on your plane, they will give your plane a selling price. 
Break the group into small teams (about 3 people per team)
The trainer should have prototyping materials ready including paper, markers, stickers, etcâ€¦ These items are available to the entrepreneurs to continue using as they want throughout the entire game. They can use whatever they want. 
Entrepreneurs are free to continue asking the trainers (the people buying the planes) questions about the activity/type of plane to design (they can do user research to find out more about how to design their plane based on customers needs/wants)
Entrepreneurs should feel free to work with their groups wherever they are comfortable

55 minutes: Activity
10 minutes: The team will have 10 minutes to design a new product (paper airplane)
10 minutes: Each group will pitch their plane to the trainer. 
The trainer will evaluate functionality, design, and the overall pitch to determine a price for each plane. 
The trainer can also consider the amount of work that went into the plane design. 
The trainer should set prices like $2, $5, $10, $15, $20 depending on detail and flying capabilities. Try to have a variety of prices.
Tell them that each plane costs $5 to make (make it all the same to keep it simple)- When we price the plane some people will get better margins or worse margins. And some people would be able to produce a lot or a little causing different levels of profitability. It depends on how the game goes, but interesting conversations come up.

15 minutes: Announce to the groups that you like all of the planes they pitched and you would like to purchase them for your store. They will have 10 minutes to produce 15 of the planes they pitched. 
When you are halfway through this time (after about 7 minutes), announce to the group that you would like to change your order. You are expecting high demand for these planes after a focus group and you would like to order 25 planes instead. 
Announce that you will extend the delivery time by 5 additional minutes (13 minutes left for production).
 15 minutes: Bring everyone back and tell people production has stopped and they need to deliver their products to you.
The trainer will now pay each group for their product
Count each plane that matches the one they pitched. Reject planes that do not work or do not match what they pitched to you.
Multiply the number of accepted planes by the price that was set before mass production. 
Subtract $5 for each plane that they made (even if the plane was rejected because they produced it)
Calculate who made the most money! 
Trainer tip: Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each $of profit they made. (Some people might owe you candy at the end if they werenâ€™t profitableâ€¦. But donâ€™t actually make them give you candy).]]]

Hereâ€™s an updated version of your activity that integrates **resource savings** and **sustainability** while maintaining the engaging and educational aspects of the original game. The adjustments encourage participants to **think critically about materials, waste, and efficiency**, tying these concepts to real-world entrepreneurship challenges.

{"updates": [{"pattern": ".*", "replacement": "### Paper Airplane Business Challenge: Resource Efficiency & Profitability

#### **5 Minutes: Explanation**
Entrepreneurs will work in groups to go through a rapid product development process.
Tell everyone they are a business developing a new product that will be sold to the training team: a paper airplane. The plane has to fly, look good, and be **produced efficiently** with minimal waste. The price will reflect its **design, functionality, and how efficiently it is produced**. Based on the trainers' thoughts on your plane, they will give your plane a selling price.

Break the group into small teams (about 3 people per team).
The trainer should have prototyping materials ready, including paper, markers, stickers, etc. These items are available to the entrepreneurs to use throughout the entire game, but **each piece of material has a cost** (e.g., each sheet of paper = $1, stickers = $0.50 each, markers = free). **The more materials used, the higher the production cost.**

Entrepreneurs are free to continue asking the trainers (the people buying the planes) questions about the activity/type of plane to design (they can do user research to find out more about how to design their plane based on customers' needs/wants).

Encourage teams to think about sustainabilityâ€”how can they use fewer materials while maintaining quality? What design choices improve efficiency? 

#### **55 Minutes: Activity**
##### **10 minutes: Design Phase**
- Teams have **10 minutes to design their airplane**, considering **performance, aesthetics, and material efficiency**.
- Encourage them to **minimize waste** by planning their design carefully.
- They should **track material usage**, as it will impact their final profit.

##### **10 minutes: Pitch Phase**
- Each group will **pitch their plane** to the trainer.
- The trainer will evaluate:
  1. **Functionality** (Does it fly well?)
  2. **Design** (Does it look good?)
  3. **Material Efficiency** (Did they use minimal resources?)
  4. **Waste Management** (Did they reuse scraps effectively?)
- The trainer will set prices like **$2, $5, $10, $15, $20**, depending on these factors.
- The **production cost** will be calculated based on materials used (e.g., paper = $1/sheet, stickers = $0.50 each, etc.).
- The trainer should highlight teams that **optimized for efficiency**.

##### **15 minutes: Scaling Up the Production**
- Announce that you like all the planes pitched and want to purchase them for your store.
- Teams have **10 minutes to produce 15 planes**.
- **Halfway through production (after 7 minutes), demand increases!**
  - A new market trend requires **25 planes instead of 15**.
  - Extend the time by **5 additional minutes (13 minutes total left for production)**.
- **Resource Constraint Twist:** The supply chain is experiencing shortages. Each team gets **only half the materials** they originally used. They must **adapt their design** or **find ways to reuse scrap materials**.

##### **15 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion**
- Stop production and **deliver the final products**.
- The trainer **evaluates the planes**:
  1. **Only accept planes that match the original design**.
  2. **Reject planes that do not meet quality standards**.
  3. **Count material usage per team**.
  4. **Calculate profit:**
     - Multiply the number of accepted planes by the selling price.
     - Subtract the material cost per plane (paper, stickers, etc.).
     - Highlight which teams made the most **profit per material used**.

- **Trainer Tip:** Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each **$ of profit per material unit used**. (This rewards efficiency!)
- Discuss which teams made the most money and **why efficiency and waste reduction matter in business**.
- Reflect on how resource scarcity impacted decisions and **how real businesses adapt to supply chain challenges**.

### **Key Learning Points:**
âœ… **Profitability depends on both price and material efficiency**.
âœ… **Resource constraints force innovation**.
âœ… **Sustainable business practices can improve margins**.
âœ… **Adaptability is key in real-world entrepreneurship**.

---
**Updated Activity Summary:** This version integrates sustainability and resource efficiency into the classic product development game, making it a more holistic entrepreneurial learning experience."}]}

Failed with error. Fix the error and try again before replying to the user.

update_textdoc cannot be called before create_textdoc

{"name": "paper_airplane_activity", "type": "document", "content": "### Paper Airplane Business Challenge: Resource Efficiency & Profitability

#### **5 Minutes: Explanation**
Entrepreneurs will work in groups to go through a rapid product development process.
Tell everyone they are a business developing a new product that will be sold to the training team: a paper airplane. The plane has to fly, look good, and be **produced efficiently** with minimal waste. The price will reflect its **design, functionality, and how efficiently it is produced**. Based on the trainers' thoughts on your plane, they will give your plane a selling price.

Break the group into small teams (about 3 people per team).
The trainer should have prototyping materials ready, including paper, markers, stickers, etc. These items are available to the entrepreneurs to use throughout the entire game, but **each piece of material has a cost** (e.g., each sheet of paper = $1, stickers = $0.50 each, markers = free). **The more materials used, the higher the production cost.**

Entrepreneurs are free to continue asking the trainers (the people buying the planes) questions about the activity/type of plane to design (they can do user research to find out more about how to design their plane based on customers' needs/wants).

Encourage teams to think about sustainabilityâ€”how can they use fewer materials while maintaining quality? What design choices improve efficiency? 

#### **55 Minutes: Activity**
##### **10 minutes: Design Phase**
- Teams have **10 minutes to design their airplane**, considering **performance, aesthetics, and material efficiency**.
- Encourage them to **minimize waste** by planning their design carefully.
- They should **track material usage**, as it will impact their final profit.

##### **10 minutes: Pitch Phase**
- Each group will **pitch their plane** to the trainer.
- The trainer will evaluate:
  1. **Functionality** (Does it fly well?)
  2. **Design** (Does it look good?)
  3. **Material Efficiency** (Did they use minimal resources?)
  4. **Waste Management** (Did they reuse scraps effectively?)
- The trainer will set prices like **$2, $5, $10, $15, $20**, depending on these factors.
- The **production cost** will be calculated based on materials used (e.g., paper = $1/sheet, stickers = $0.50 each, etc.).
- The trainer should highlight teams that **optimized for efficiency**.

##### **15 minutes: Scaling Up the Production**
- Announce that you like all the planes pitched and want to purchase them for your store.
- Teams have **10 minutes to produce 15 planes**.
- **Halfway through production (after 7 minutes), demand increases!**
  - A new market trend requires **25 planes instead of 15**.
  - Extend the time by **5 additional minutes (13 minutes total left for production)**.
- **Resource Constraint Twist:** The supply chain is experiencing shortages. Each team gets **only half the materials** they originally used. They must **adapt their design** or **find ways to reuse scrap materials**.

##### **15 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion**
- Stop production and **deliver the final products**.
- The trainer **evaluates the planes**:
  1. **Only accept planes that match the original design**.
  2. **Reject planes that do not meet quality standards**.
  3. **Count material usage per team**.
  4. **Calculate profit:**
     - Multiply the number of accepted planes by the selling price.
     - Subtract the material cost per plane (paper, stickers, etc.).
     - Highlight which teams made the most **profit per material used**.

- **Trainer Tip:** Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each **$ of profit per material unit used**. (This rewards efficiency!)
- Discuss which teams made the most money and **why efficiency and waste reduction matter in business**.
- Reflect on how resource scarcity impacted decisions and **how real businesses adapt to supply chain challenges**.

### **Key Learning Points:**
âœ… **Profitability depends on both price and material efficiency**.
âœ… **Resource constraints force innovation**.
âœ… **Sustainable business practices can improve margins**.
âœ… **Adaptability is key in real-world entrepreneurship**.

---
**Updated Activity Summary:** This version integrates sustainability and resource efficiency into the classic product development game, making it a more holistic entrepreneurial learning experience."}
Successfully created text document 'Paper Airplane Activity' which will be referenced in all future messages with the unique identifier textdoc_id: '67c87b4bb0f481919494feb6b72e41f0'

I've updated your activity to integrate **resource efficiency and sustainability**, making it more relevant to real-world entrepreneurship challenges. Let me know if you'd like further refinements! ðŸš€

can you simplify this? 
Re-evaluate your supply chain and identify at least 3 ways you can create value in your supply chain (reduce costs, streamline processes, track and measure more efficiently)
One way to do this is by completing the Business Efficiency Checklist for your enterprise 
Prioritize high-impact improvements using the matrix - Create a concrete action plan with timelines and responsibilities
Remember: The most successful businesses integrate efficiency and sustainability into their core operations

Review your supply chain and find **three ways to improve efficiency** (cut costs, simplify processes, or track better).  

Use the **Business Efficiency Checklist** to guide you.  

Prioritize **high-impact changes** with the matrix and create a clear **action plan** with deadlines and responsibilities.  

**Key Tip:** The best businesses make efficiency and sustainability a core focus!
can the paper airplane game be made simpler and also help people start to think about potentially using the same paper ot make more than one plane and to reduce risk made from cutting paper

{"updates": [{"pattern": ".*", "replacement": "### Paper Airplane Business Challenge: Efficiency & Smart Resource Use

#### **5 Minutes: Explanation**
Entrepreneurs will work in small teams to design and sell a paper airplane. The goal is to make a plane that **flies well, looks good, and is made efficiently** with minimal waste. The trainer (buyer) will set a price based on these factors.

Each team gets **limited materials** (e.g., 2 sheets of paper per team). They can **use creative folding, reuse scraps, or share materials** to maximize output. 

Encourage teams to ask the buyer about preferences before designing their plane.

#### **45 Minutes: Activity**
##### **10 minutes: Design Phase**
- Teams have **10 minutes to design their plane** while minimizing waste.
- **Bonus challenge:** Can they make two planes from one sheet?
- Cutting paper **increases risk**â€”if done poorly, it may ruin the material.

##### **10 minutes: Pitch Phase**
- Each team presents their plane.
- The trainer evaluates:
  1. **Flight performance**
  2. **Design appeal**
  3. **Material efficiency** (planes per sheet, minimal waste)
- Planes receive a price based on these factors.

##### **15 minutes: Production Challenge**
- Teams **produce as many planes as they can** in 10 minutes.
- **Surprise twist**: After 5 minutes, demand changes! More planes are needed, but teams have **only their remaining materials**.
- Encourage **collaboration and adaptation** (e.g., using scraps, folding smarter).

##### **10 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion**
- Count planes and calculate earnings (price per plane minus material costs).
- Highlight teams that **reduced waste, made multiple planes per sheet, or adapted well**.
- Discuss: How do real businesses balance quality, efficiency, and risk?

### **Key Takeaways:**
âœ… **Less waste = more profit**
âœ… **Smart design reduces risk and increases output**
âœ… **Adaptability is key in business**"}]}
Successfully updated text document with textdoc_id '67c87b4bb0f481919494feb6b72e41f0'
I've simplified the activity while integrating the ideas of **reducing waste, reusing materials, and minimizing risk from cutting paper**. Let me know if you'd like any further refinements! ðŸš€

they should be able to buy more paper, etc - let's make it more subtle that they can cut and make more planes with one paper - what's the most interesting way to update this game to make it about resource efficiency and waste management ### Paper Airplane Business Challenge: Efficiency & Smart Resource Use

#### **5 Minutes: Explanation**
Entrepreneurs will work in small teams to design and sell a paper airplane. The goal is to make a plane that **flies well, looks good, and is made efficiently** with minimal waste. The trainer (buyer) will set a price based on these factors.

Each team gets **limited materials** (e.g., 2 sheets of paper per team). They can **use creative folding, reuse scraps, or share materials** to maximize output. 

Encourage teams to ask the buyer about preferences before designing their plane.

#### **45 Minutes: Activity**
##### **10 minutes: Design Phase**
- Teams have **10 minutes to design their plane** while minimizing waste.
- **Bonus challenge:** Can they make two planes from one sheet?
- Cutting paper **increases risk**â€”if done poorly, it may ruin the material.

##### **10 minutes: Pitch Phase**
- Each team presents their plane.
- The trainer evaluates:
  1. **Flight performance**
  2. **Design appeal**
  3. **Material efficiency** (planes per sheet, minimal waste)
- Planes receive a price based on these factors.

##### **15 minutes: Production Challenge**
- Teams **produce as many planes as they can** in 10 minutes.
- **Surprise twist**: After 5 minutes, demand changes! More planes are needed, but teams have **only their remaining materials**.
- Encourage **collaboration and adaptation** (e.g., using scraps, folding smarter).

##### **10 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion**
- Count planes and calculate earnings (price per plane minus material costs).
- Highlight teams that **reduced waste, made multiple planes per sheet, or adapted well**.
- Discuss: How do real businesses balance quality, efficiency, and risk?

### **Key Takeaways:**
âœ… **Less waste = more profit**
âœ… **Smart design reduces risk and increases output**
âœ… **Adaptability is key in business**

{"updates": [{"pattern": ".*", "replacement": "### Paper Airplane Business Challenge: Efficiency & Smart Resource Use

#### **5 Minutes: Explanation**
Entrepreneurs will work in small teams to design and sell a paper airplane. The goal is to make a plane that **flies well, looks good, and is made efficiently** with minimal waste. The trainer (buyer) will set a price based on these factors.

Each team starts with **a limited supply of materials** (e.g., 2 sheets of paper per team). However, they can **buy additional materials** if needed, though this will reduce their final profits. Encourage teams to **use creative folding, reuse scraps, or optimize designs** to get the most out of their materials.

Encourage teams to ask the buyer about preferences before designing their plane.

#### **45 Minutes: Activity**
##### **10 minutes: Design Phase**
- Teams have **10 minutes to design their plane** while minimizing waste.
- **Bonus challenge:** Can they make multiple planes from one sheet without reducing quality?
- Cutting paper **increases risk**â€”if done poorly, it may ruin the material.

##### **10 minutes: Pitch Phase**
- Each team presents their plane.
- The trainer evaluates:
  1. **Flight performance**
  2. **Design appeal**
  3. **Material efficiency** (planes per sheet, minimal waste)
- Planes receive a price based on these factors.

##### **15 minutes: Production Challenge**
- Teams **produce as many planes as they can** in 10 minutes.
- **Materials Store Opens**: Teams can **purchase extra paper** ($2 per sheet) if they need more materials, but this will impact their final profit.
- **Surprise twist**: After 5 minutes, demand changes! More planes are needed, and teams must decide how to **meet demand efficiently without overspending on materials**.
- Encourage **collaboration and adaptation** (e.g., using scraps, folding smarter, sharing techniques).

##### **10 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion**
- Count planes and calculate earnings (price per plane minus material costs).
- Highlight teams that **reduced waste, made multiple planes per sheet, or adapted well**.
- Discuss:
  1. How did material costs impact profits?
  2. Did anyone successfully reuse scraps or reduce waste?
  3. How do real businesses balance quality, efficiency, and resource management?

### **Key Takeaways:**
âœ… **Less waste = more profit**
âœ… **Smart design reduces risk and increases output**
âœ… **Spending wisely on materials impacts the bottom line**
âœ… **Adaptability is key in business**"}]}

I've refined the activity to subtly encourage teams to consider **buying more paper**, while still focusing on **resource efficiency and waste management**. Let me know if youâ€™d like any further tweaks! ðŸš€
